titleStmt.title: A European Multicenter Study of 616 Patients Receiving the Freedom Solo Stentless Bioprosthesis

affiliation.orgName: University Hospital Gent Hospital S. João

analytic.title: A European Multicenter Study of 616 Patients Receiving the Freedom Solo Stentless Bioprosthesis

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Background.
The purpose of this study was to evaluate the safety and performance of the Freedom Solo valve in aortic valve replacement by clinical and hemodynamic outcomes.
Methods.

Six hundred sixteen patients underwent aortic valve replacement in 18 European centers; mean age was 74.5 ± 5.9 years, 54.1% of the patients were male, and concomitant procedures were performed in 43.2% of the patients.
The majority (69%) of the implanted sizes were 23 mm and 25 mm.
Results.
At 1 year, overall survival was 94.0%, whereas freedom from valve-related death was 98.6%.
There were 9 (1.5%) early (£30 days) and 27 (4.4%)
late (>30 days) deaths.
Early and late valve-related mortality was 0.3% (n [ 2) and 1.1% (n [ 7), respectively.
Freedom from explant was 97.6%; 10 valves were explanted for endocarditis and 4 for paravalvular leak.
There were 10 (1.6%) early and 5 (0.8%) late strokes.
Atrioventricular block requiring pacemaker implant occurred in 8 (1.3%) and 1 (0.2%) patients in the early and late postoperative period, respectively.
Thrombocytopenia was seen in 27 cases (4.4%) in the early postoperative period.

Preoperatively, 93.8% of patients were in New York Heart Association functional classes II through IV, whereas at 1 year 96.9% of patients were in New York Heart Association functional classes I and II.
At 1-year follow-up, mean and peak pressure gradients were 7.2 and 14.6 mm Hg, respectively.
Indexed left ventricular mass decreased by 12% from 138 g/m 2 at discharge to 122 g/m 2 at 1 year.
Conclusions.

At 1-year follow-up after Freedom Solo implantation, we found acceptable clinical results with low mortality and morbidity and good hemodynamic performance, confirming safety and effectiveness in this multicenter experience.

(Ann Thorac Surg 2016;101:100-9) Ó 2016 by The Society of Thoracic Surgeons T he Freedom Solo (FS) valve (Sorin Group, Saluggia, Italy) is a bovine pericardial aortic stentless prosthesis introduced in 2004 as a modification of the Pericarbon Freedom stentless valve (Sorin Group) [1].
The unique design allows the valve to be implanted in a supra annular position using a single suture line, as documented in several reports [2][3][4][5][6].
Moreover, the excellent hemodynamics resulting from the complete supra annular implant have also been described extensively [7][8][9][10][11][12][13][14].
The FS has been commercially available in Europe since 2004, and was approved in the United States in 2014.
Hence most of the published data are related to experiences with a fairly small numbers of patients.
The present prospective multicenter study was undertaken to further confirm the existing knowledge about the clinical and hemodynamic performance of the FS in a large patient cohort.
This prospective, multicenter, nonrandomized trial included 18 centers from 8 European countries, and was registered with the US National Institutes of Health (NCT00876525, www.clinicaltrials.org).
Patients were enrolled as part of a US Food and Drug Administration study.
Patients were referred for native or prosthetic aortic valve replacement and had to be at least 18 years old and capable of providing written informed consent.
Patients with previously implanted mitral or tricuspid prostheses, active endocarditis, or congenital bicuspid valves or those requiring concomitant valve replacement were excluded.
Clinical examination and transthoracic echocardiography were performed after hospital discharge, at 3 to 6 months, and at 1-year follow-up (follow-up window, 11 to 13 months).
The ethical committee of each center approved the study.
An independent Clinical Events Committee adjudicated the reason for primary cause of death, valve explant, and specific adverse events.

The FS consists of two pericardial sheets: the inner sheet originates the three valvular cusps, and the outer sheet is trimmed as a collar that allows the valve to be sutured to the aortic wall (Fig 1).

Pericardium is fixed using a lowpressure glutaraldehyde solution and detoxified with homocysteic acid, which has been demonstrated to reduce mineralization in vitro and in vivo through the neutralization of unbound glutaraldehyde groups [15].

Although the Pericarbon Freedom stentless valve required two suture lines during implantation, the FS can be implanted with a single suture line in a totally supra annular position, following O'Brien's technique (Fig 2) [3][4][5][6].
Seven hundred two patients were recruited for the study between March 2009 and September 2012.

Eleven patients were withdrawn before surgery, and 75 patients were excluded during the procedure: 17 for heavily calcified aortic root, 15 for bicuspid valve discovered intraoperatively, and 43 for other anatomic reasons.
Eventually, 616 patients received the FS (mean age, 74.5 AE 5.9 years; male, 54.1%; log EuroSCORE, 10.1% AE 8%).
Systemic hypertension, dyslipidemia, and coronary artery disease were the main risk factors in the patient cohort (Fig 3).
The indication for aortic valve replacement was symptomatic pure stenosis in 410 patients (66.5%), mixed lesion in 197 patients (32.0%), and regurgitation in 8 patients (1.3%; Table 1).
Full median sternotomy (90.6%) or limited partial sternotomy (9.4%) were used as the surgical approach.
Myocardial protection was achieved with cold crystalloid or blood cardioplegic solution delivered in antegrade or retrograde fashion, according to the surgeon's preference.
The aorta was opened with a transverse incision approximately 1 cm above the sinotubular junction, and the valve was excised with debridement of the annulus.
Valve sizing was performed, choosing the labeled valve size corresponding to the sizer that comfortably passed through the annulus.
Care was taken to not oversize the valve because the FS is already upsized by the manufacturer to obtain the best supra annular seating.
The valve was implanted through a single continuous suture line as described previously [3,6].
After weaning from cardiopulmonary bypass, transesophageal echocardiography was performed.
Anticoagulation therapy was administered according to each centers' standard practice for biologic valves.

Medical history, physical examination, laboratory results, electrocardiogram, New York Heart Association functional class assessment, and echocardiography were reported as per the study protocol preoperatively, at discharge, after 3 to 6 months, and at 1 year; follow-up was complete (100%) in all 544 active patients at 1 year (22 patients withdrew, 36 deaths, and 14 explants).
Data collection aimed at evaluating early ( 30 days) and late (>30 days) postoperative outcomes along with the rate of adverse events, reported according to established guidelines [16].
Hemodynamic performance of the FS was assessed using quantitative echocardiography in all patients, as established by the protocol.
Patients' echocardiographic examinations were read by an independent core laboratory.
Both the left ventricle (LV) and the aorta were recorded in a two-dimensional parasternal and four-chamber view.
Aortic geometry and diameters were registered in a parasternal long-axis view.
Subaortic and aortic Doppler flow velocities were recorded in the apical four-chamber view using pulsed-wave and continuous-wave Doppler mode.
Peak and mean aortic valve pressure gradients were calculated from the velocity measurements with a modified Bernoulli equation.
The LV mass was calculated according to the American Society of Echocardiography recommended formula and indexed to the body surface area to generate the LV mass index [17].
Periodic blood samples were drawn to evaluate postoperative platelet trending.
Platelet counts were assessed according to the protocol.
Thrombocytopenia was considered "severe" when the platelet count dropped to less than 50,000/mL [18].
Cumulative survival and freedom from events were estimated through the Kaplan-Meier method, with 95% confidence intervals (95% CI).
For comparative analysis, hemodynamic data were expressed as mean AE standard deviations (SD) or median.
For descriptive analysis, data were expressed as number and percentage.
Student's t test was applied to compare echocardiographic data as a function of time.
Statistical analyses were performed using SAS software (release 9.2; SAS Institute Inc, Cary, NC).
A probability value of less than 0.05 was considered to be statistically significant.
Table 2 provides the operative results.
Approximately 50% of this cohort received a 23-mm valve or smaller.
One or more concomitant procedures were required in 43.2% of patients, with coronary artery bypass grafting being the most common (91.4%).
Mean aortic cross-clamp time was 64 minutes for isolated aortic valve replacement and greater than 71 minutes when additional procedures were required.
There were 9 deaths during the first 30 days after surgery (30-day mortality, 1.5%).
All of them were classified by the Clinical Event Committee.

Five deaths were classified as noncardiac causes, specifically stroke (2 patients), both occurred on the same day of surgery and were adjudicated as procedure-related, and multiorgan failure (3 patients); 2 deaths were classified as non-valve-related cardiac causes, myocardial infarction (1 patient) and ventricular arrhythmia (1 patient); and 2 deaths (0.3%) were classified as valve-related, 1 stroke and 1 sudden death (Table 3).
One-year mortality was 4.5% (27 deaths).

Seven deaths were adjudicated as valve-related (1.1%; Table 3), caused by cerebral bleeding (2 patients), endocarditis (1 patient), sudden death (1 patient), stroke (1 patient), bleeding (1 patient), and reoperation as a result of aortic regurgitation (1 patient).
Four deaths were classified as cardiacrelated, specifically progressive heart failure (2 patients) and myocardial infarction (2 patients).

The remaining 16 deaths were classified as non-cardiac-related: cerebral bleeding (2 patients) in patients with concomitant disease, carcinoma and lymphoma (2 patients), pulmonary embolism (1 patient), sepsis (8 patients), stroke (1 patient) in a high-risk patient with a history of thromboembolism, and other uncategorized causes (2 patients).
Actuarial 1-year overall survival and freedom from valve-related death were 94.0% (95% CI, 91.7 to 95.6) and 98.6% (95% CI, 97.3 to 99.3), respectively (Fig 4).
Twenty-eight patients (4.5%) underwent early reoperation for bleeding at the surgical site, with 23 of them being performed on the day of surgery (Table 4).
Other early adverse events included 1 patient who required a valve explant for endocarditis, and 2 patients who needed a valve explant for paravalvular leakage.
Ten patients (1.6%) had early stroke, resulting in 3 deaths.
Nineteen patients required a pacemaker implant (3.1%); in 8 patients (1.3%) this was a new atrioventricular conduction abnormality.
Three patients experienced early myocardial infarction (0.5%), with 1 death.
Late adverse events included 9 explants for endocarditis, 2 explants for paravalvular leakage, and 1 explant for structural valve deterioration (Table 4).
Five patients (0.8%) experienced late strokes, 2 of them fatal, whereas 1 patient who had a stroke in the early postoperative period died after 30 days.
Three patients required a pacemaker implant during late follow-up, 1 for a new atrioventricular conduction problem.
Five late cases of myocardial infarction (0.8%) were reported, 2 of them leading to death.
Valve thrombosis was described in 1 patient at 5 months after surgery, but was successfully resolved by modifying the anticoagulation therapy.
One-year freedom from all-cause explant was 97.6% (95% CI, 95.9 to 98.6; Fig 5), whereas freedom from structural valve deterioration was 99.8% (95% CI, 98.6 to 100).
Freedom from endocarditis, valve thrombosis, and non-structural valve dysfunction at 1 year were 97.9%, 99.7%, and 98.5%, respectively.
At 1 year, 96.9% of patients were in New York Heart Association functional class I or II (Table 5).
Valve gradients and effective orifice area at discharge were maintained at 1-year follow-up (Fig 6).
Overall mean pressure gradient was 6.9 AE 4.5 mm Hg and 7.2 AE 4.0 at discharge and 1 year, respectively.
Overall peak pressure gradient at discharge was 13.7 AE 8.7 mm Hg, whereas at 1 year it was 14.6 AE 7.9 mm Hg.
Overall effective orifice area was 1.6 AE 0.4 cm 2 and 1.5 AE 0.5 cm 2 at discharge and 1 year, respectively.
There was no significant difference between pressure gradients and effective orifice area both at discharge and during follow-up.
Indexed LV mass was 138 g/m 2 at discharge, 129 g/m 2 at 3 to 6 months, and 122 g/m 2 at 1 year, reflecting a decrease of 12% (p < 0.001; Fig 7).
No cases of severe regurgitation were reported at each follow-up.
and negative heparin-induced thrombocytopenia antibody test required re-exploration for bleeding on the day of surgery, while 4 patients received a single unit of transfused platelets.
The remaining patients with early low platelet counts didn't experience any valve-related complications within the first year of follow-up.
Historically, tissue heart valves were anticipated to last for 10 to 15 years before calcific degeneration required their replacement.

Subsequent improvements in valve design and biologic materials have further reduced the rate of valve calcification and reoperation, with particular relevance in the elderly population, in which prolonged durability of bioprosthetic valves has been broadly reported [15,19].
Stentless valves were introduced into clinical practice in the early 1990s with the goal of further improving clinical outcomes.
They were designed to be less obstructive to achieve lower transvalvular gradients and faster reduction of ventricular hypertrophy, but their implant technique was usually more complex and demanding.
The resulting prolonged aortic cross-clamp and surgical procedure times led to a limited adoption of these first-generation stentless valves.

Repossini and colleagues [6] first described a single suture line technique with a modified Pericarbon Freedom stentless valve that resulted in a simplified procedure, optimizing at the same time hemodynamic performance thanks to the supra annular position.
The valve gained immediate interest because of the excellent clinical and hemodynamics [9] and the reduced cross-clamp time resulting from the modified implant technique [3].
The present study reports clinical and hemodynamic results from a prospective multicenter trial, representing the largest published experience with the FS at 1 year.

Furthermore, it demonstrates that implantation of the FS can be achieved with mean cross-clamp times, procedure times, and hemodynamic performance comparable with surgically inserted stented aortic valve prostheses [20].

No intraoperative deaths were reported in the present series, and the low 30-day mortality (1.5%) demonstrates that good short-term clinical outcome can be achieved, despite the advance age of the cohort (80% of patients were older than 70 years).

Although there were a large number of risk factors, early and late mortality were comparable to those reported by Beholz and associates [9], with 1-year survival of 94.0% versus 90.4% and equivalent freedom from valve explant and endocarditis.
Adverse valve-related events, such as stroke, endocarditis, structural valve deterioration, nonstructural valve dysfunction, and valve thrombosis, were also rare in this series.
Hemodynamic performance was excellent as reflected by the functional status after surgery with 97% of the surviving patients in New York Heart Association functional classes I and II at 1 year.

The mean pressure gradient of 6.9 mm Hg in the early postoperative period increased trivially to no more than 7.2 mm Hg by the end of the first year with stable and low gradients observed in the small sizes as well.
As a result of these excellent hemodynamics, the mean LV mass index decreased by 12% in 1 year.
The current data confirm the results from a previous Italian multicenter study [14].
The same study showed progressive reduction of the LV mass index from the immediate postoperative period throughout the 1-year follow-up.
In this study patients also underwent a stress echocardiography, which demonstrated a well-preserved hemodynamic profile of the FS during exercise.

Superior hemodynamic performance of the FS is achieved by the supra annular seating, which aligns the valve orifice to the patient's tissue annulus, preventing any impingement in the sewing ring, as previously reported [9,11].
According to Jamieson and colleagues [21], age is a risk factor for endocarditis.

Comparing cohorts of patients with the same mean age [22,23], endocarditis rates in this study compare favorably both in the early period (0.3% versus 0.5%) and at 1-year follow-up (97.6% versus 96.0%).
Similar data are reported by Beholz and associates [9].

The indication for a permanent pacemaker implant for complete atrioventricular block was less common (1.3%) in the present series than in studies for other valves, in which it ranged from 3% to 6.6% [24,25].

One of these experiences demonstrated a statistically significant increase of the 30-day mortality in patients requiring a pacemaker implant (4.2%) versus patients not requiring it (1%; p ¼ 0.046) [25].

Although it cannot be unequivocally proven by this study alone, the low incidence of postoperative atrioventricular block may be related to the supra annular implant position of the FS and the relatively reduced compression on the bundle of His.
Similar low rates of permanent pacemaker implants have been reported in a previous experience with the FS [2].
In the present study cohort, few postoperative bleeding complications were observed and were comparable to what is reported in the literature [2].

Severe thrombocytopenia was observed in the early postoperative period also in this cohort as already described [18,[26][27][28][29][30], even though less frequently (Fig 8) than in the previous studies in which it ranged from 15% to 25% [18,31,32].

In a recent experience comparing the FS with the Edwards Perimount valve (Edwards Life-Sciences, Irvine, CA) in terms of perioperative hematologic variables, Pozzoli and coworkers [18] demonstrated that the incidence of severe thrombocytopenia (platelet count <50,000/mL) in patients receiving the FS was significantly greater than in patients receiving the Perimount valve (15% versus 2%, respectively; p ¼ 0.001).

Nevertheless, the two groups of patients showed no difference in morbidity, and the FS group had no significant increase in hemorrhagic complications, nor did they require more transfusions or reexploration for bleeding.
Severe thrombocytopenia in the FS patients recovered after the immediate postoperative period in all cases.
Other studies have documented the absence of functional impairment of platelets in patients with the FS and thrombocytopenia, as measured by thromboelastography or aggregometry studies [31,32].
Published series also described the self-limited nature of thrombocytopenia after an FS implant and the relative absence of morbidity [18,27,28,31,32].
Despite the observation that thrombocytopenia after an FS implant appears to be limited and not associated with increased morbidity, to date this phenomenon clearly deserves additional study.
It has been suggested that the complete supra annular positioning of the FS might expose a significant area of freshly decalcified annulus, triggering platelet adhesion [18].

The observed lower incidence of thrombocytopenia from the experienced high-volume centers that contributed to the present series could certainly be further investigated to understand whether a suboptimal implantation plays a role in the immediate postoperative platelet drop.
The main limitation of the present study is the short follow-up period.
We report 1-year findings with the intention to provide additional reports in the future to determine mid-term performance of the FS.

Finally, although laboratory data regarding postoperative thrombocytopenia after the FS implant were shown, it must be clarified that this study was not designed to specifically investigate the etiology of this phenomenon.

This multicenter European study has confirmed previous findings from single-center studies about safety and hemodynamic performance of the FS aortic valve, in which the FS aortic valve conveys excellent hemodynamics as would be expected with a stentless valve.
To our knowledge, the present study represents the largest experience that has yet appeared in the literature with the FS.
It confirms the excellent results in terms of morbidity, mortality, and low rates of valve-related adverse events during short-term follow-up.
In addition, the valve demonstrated excellent hemodynamics, leading to a reduction in LV mass and to the patients' excellent functional status.
Monitoring this cohort over time will
